ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were sometimes lectures and student presentations.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: German grammar skills and reading skills
An elementary reading knowledge of German.
I began to learn how to read German. The process is nowhere near complete.
We learned broad sweeps of German grammar, some academia focused vocabulary, and practiced translating excerpts of academic work.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The method of instruction was nonsensical. The homework load was absurd and oftentimes was busywork.
A slower pace would have helped me to absorb more of the German grammar and vocabulary.

The course's textbook is terribly organized and desperately needs to be updated. The classes should also be organized better with clearer expectations of what is happening in class and what should be prepared at home. Assessment items have also not been updated since 2018, and the present instructor clearly was not familiar with the documents.

The course covers a wide breadth of material and the final project of translating part of an academic work if your choosing is the the strongest part of the course. Unfortunately, the broad grammar topics covered in one semester means that it was very rushed. The class follows the German for Reading Knowledge which is frankly not well organized, an issue which is reflected in the class overall.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We started out having breaks and then stopped--what's up with that? Stopping breaks and then later saying we had to have our cameras on was just way too much.

We took our midterm and final as a live, proctored exam. In the end it was fine, but the rules were very unclear, especially in regards to dictionary use, up until the day of the exam. If that could be made clearer or added as a policy on the syllabus, it would be much smoother.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If someone needs German reading it's kinda their only option (and the only reason they'd take it). So this is rather irrelevant, no?
Only if they want an introduction to reading German.

I would not generally recommend this course to anyone not strictly looking to read German for academic purposes AND who wants an extra study motivator through deadlines. The material is covered quickly and in a rather disorganized fashion, but provides a good starting point for all the various grammar topics you should study on your own. If you are looking to speak German, or just for everyday usage, skip this class and go to L1.
